Content: I remember reading this somewhere but I cannot locate the proof.
AcceptedAnswer: It is the smallest prime factor that is less than or equal to $\sqrt{n}$, unless $n$ is prime.  One proof is as follows: Suppose $n=ab$ and $a$ is the smallest prime factor of $n$, and $n$ is not prime.  Since $n$ is not prime, we have $b\ne1$.  Since $a$ is the smallest prime factor of $n$, we have $a\le b$.  If $a$ were bigger than $\sqrt{n}$, then $b$ would also be bigger than $\sqrt{n}$, so $ab$ would be bigger than $\sqrt{n}\cdot\sqrt{n}$.  But $ab=n$.
